Stem: Three cardboard screens with holes are placed in a straight line with a light source behind the third screen. The middle screen is shifted out of alignment. What happens to the light visible through the first screen?
Image/Diagram Description: Diagram showing three screens with holes in a line and a light source behind the third screen
Choices: A) The light bends around the middle screen, B) The light dims but is still visible, C) The light is no longer visible because light travels in straight lines, D) The light reflects off the middle screen and becomes brighter
Scenario Justification: Strong experimental scenario with manipulable setup. Students must predict the result of shifting a screen based on the principle that light travels in straight lines. Anchored in an observable and testable phenomenon.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation predicting the outcome of a physical change. Engages Constructing Explanations by linking the property of light traveling in straight lines to the predicted observation.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that light travels in straight lines and cannot bend around opaque obstacles. Applied understanding of light behavior beyond simple recall.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — shifting the screen (cause) blocks the straight-line path of light (effect). Students must reason causally about why the light is no longer visible.
Key Recommendation: Strong phenomenon-based question. Elevate by asking a Part B: What would happen if the middle screen had a larger hole? This would deepen Cause and Effect reasoning.

Stem: A new organism is discovered with the following characteristics: maintains constant body temperature; has a waterproof covering with hair; gives birth to live young; produces nutritious fluid for its young; has specialized limbs. Which group does this organism most likely belong to?
Choices: A) Reptiles, B) Amphibians, C) Birds, D) Mammals
Scenario Justification: Presents an unfamiliar organism with multiple traits that must be matched to a classification group. Students must analyze several characteristics rather than just one. Some reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students analyze multiple pieces of evidence (traits) to classify an unknown organism. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data by evaluating which combination of traits matches a known group.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the defining characteristics of mammals — live birth, hair, milk production, constant body temperature. Applied understanding of organism classification beyond simple recall.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns (recognizing a pattern of traits that defines a group) but students do not explicitly reason with the CCC as a tool.
Key Recommendation: Good multi-trait classification. Strengthen by presenting two organisms with overlapping traits and asking students to explain which traits are most diagnostic using Patterns reasoning.

Stem: A patient has a blocked artery leading to the left leg. Which sequence BEST explains the consequences of this blockage?
Choices: A) Reduced blood flow leads to less oxygen delivery leads to anaerobic respiration leads to lactic acid buildup leads to pain and fatigue, B) Increased blood flow leads to swelling leads to numbness, C) Blood flows backward causing bruising, D) The leg receives too much oxygen causing burning
Scenario Justification: Strong medical scenario requiring multi-step causal reasoning about how a blockage cascades through body systems. Students must trace a chain of physiological consequences. Genuine complexity.
SEP Justification: Students construct a multi-step explanation tracing cause through multiple physiological effects. Engages Constructing Explanations at a high level with sequential causal reasoning through a system.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding circulatory function, oxygen delivery, cellular respiration, and waste products. Goes well beyond Grade 4 expectations into middle school life science content (anaerobic respiration, lactic acid). Advanced DCI demand.
CCC Justification: Strongly engages Cause and Effect — multi-step causal chain where each effect becomes the cause of the next. Also engages Systems and System Models as students reason about interconnected body systems.
Key Recommendation: Strong causal reasoning but content (anaerobic respiration and lactic acid) is well beyond Grade 4 NGSS expectations. This is middle school (MS-LS1) content. Simplify to grade-appropriate physiology while maintaining the causal chain structure.

Stem: Scientists studied how different animals digest food — bears digest salmon, horses break down grass, and snakes swallow whole prey. Which is the most accurate statement about these animals?
Choices: A) All three animals digest food in exactly the same way, B) Only bears can absorb nutrients because they eat meat, C) All have specialized adaptations but share the fundamental process of nutrient absorption, D) Snakes do not need to digest food because they swallow prey whole
Scenario Justification: Comparative scenario across three animals with different diets and digestive strategies. Students must identify a unifying principle across varied examples.
SEP Justification: Students analyze evidence from multiple organisms to identify a shared biological principle. Engages Constructing Explanations by synthesizing observations across examples.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that while digestive adaptations vary, nutrient absorption is a shared fundamental process. Applied understanding of internal structures and their functions.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — students must recognize the pattern that despite surface-level differences, all animals share the same fundamental process. Also engages Structure and Function.
Key Recommendation: Good comparative question. Strengthen by providing specific data about digestion times or nutrient extraction efficiency for each animal and asking students to explain the pattern.

Stem: Scientists are studying organisms in a region experiencing climate change. Which statement BEST explains how a trait functions as an adaptation that helps an organism survive?
Choices: A) A tree with deep roots can access groundwater during extended drought periods, B) A fish swims fast in a river, C) A bird has feathers for flying, D) A dog pants when it is hot
Scenario Justification: Presents a climate change context requiring students to distinguish between a true adaptation explanation (trait linked to survival advantage in a specific challenge) and simple trait descriptions.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate multiple claims to determine which best explains adaptation. Engages Engaging in Argument from Evidence by selecting the most complete explanation.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that adaptations are traits specifically linked to survival in particular environmental conditions. Goes beyond naming traits to explaining function in context.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — the deep roots (cause) enable survival during drought (effect). Also engages Structure and Function — root structure serves the function of accessing deep water.
Key Recommendation: Good question requiring students to distinguish between a complete adaptation explanation and simple trait descriptions. Could elevate by providing data on root depths and drought survival rates.

Stem: A rabbit detects the scent of a predator and freezes in place. Which sequence best describes how the rabbit's body systems work together to produce this response?
Choices: A) Muscles detect the scent and tell the brain to freeze, B) Nervous system receives scent signal and transmits it to the brain which sends signals to the muscles causing the rabbit to freeze, C) The rabbit's eyes see the predator and the bones lock in place, D) The skin detects danger and the lungs stop working
Scenario Justification: Strong multi-system scenario where students must trace sensory information through the nervous system to a motor response. Real-world survival context with sequential reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students construct a sequential explanation tracing information from sensory input through processing to motor output. Engages Constructing Explanations at a high level with system-level reasoning.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding how sensory organs detect stimuli, nerves transmit signals to the brain, and the brain sends signals to muscles for a response. Applied understanding of information processing.
CCC Justification: Strongly engages Systems and System Models — students reason about how multiple body systems (nervous, muscular, sensory) interact as an integrated system. Also engages Cause and Effect in the causal chain.
Key Recommendation: Excellent systems-level question. One of the strongest items on this test. Could add a Part B asking what would happen if the nerve pathway to the muscles were damaged.

Stem: A rock sample has two distinct layers. The bottom layer contains fossilized seashells. The top layer contains fossilized tree roots and leaves. What does this rock tell us about the history of this area?
Choices: A) The area was once covered by ocean and later became dry land, B) Trees grew underwater alongside the seashells, C) The seashells were carried to the area by wind, D) The rock layers formed at the same time
Scenario Justification: Real geological scenario with fossil evidence in two layers. Students must interpret the sequence of environments from fossil evidence and apply superposition. Genuine reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students analyze fossil evidence to construct an explanation of environmental change over time. Engages Constructing Explanations from evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that fossils indicate past environments and that the bottom layer is older. Applied understanding of Earth's history through rock layer evidence.
CCC Justification: Engages Stability and Change — the area transitioned from ocean to land over time. Students reason about environmental change as recorded in rock layers.
Key Recommendation: Solid question connecting fossil evidence to environmental history. Strengthen by adding a third layer and asking students to reconstruct the full sequence of environmental changes.

Stem: When pieces of rock are broken down and carried away by a river, what process is occurring?
Choices: A) Weathering, B) Deposition, C) Erosion, D) Volcanic activity
Scenario Justification: No real scenario. Direct recall of the definition of erosion. The stem essentially defines erosion and asks students to name it.
SEP Justification: No science practice engaged. Pure vocabulary recall — matching a description to a term.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge of the definition of erosion. Recall-level understanding with no application.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure vocabulary recall. Redesign to present a scenario with multiple Earth surface processes occurring simultaneously and ask students to identify and explain each process.

Stem: Which statement BEST describes how erosion changes the landscape over time?
Choices: A) Flowing water gradually wears away rock creating canyons and valleys over millions of years, B) Erosion only happens during major storms, C) Erosion builds up mountains over time, D) Erosion only affects soft materials like sand
Scenario Justification: Asks for a general description of erosion over time. Some conceptual understanding required but the correct answer is essentially a textbook definition.
SEP Justification: Students select the best description of a process. Limited practice engagement — identifying the most accurate general statement.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that erosion is a gradual process that shapes landforms over long periods. Recall-level understanding with minimal application.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Stability and Change (gradual change over time) but students do not explicitly reason with the CCC.
Key Recommendation: Essentially a recall question about erosion. Redesign to provide before-and-after images or data about a specific landscape and ask students to explain the changes using evidence.

Stem: A hiking club is studying a topographic map where contour lines are at 50-meter intervals. On the north side contour lines are 1 cm apart; east side 0.5 cm apart; south side 2 cm apart; west side 1.5 cm apart. To minimize steepness climbing to the summit, from which direction should they approach?
Image/Diagram Description: Topographic map showing different contour line spacings on four sides
Choices: A) North, B) South, C) East, D) West
Scenario Justification: Strong applied scenario requiring quantitative reasoning about topographic maps. Students must connect contour line spacing to slope steepness and apply this understanding to make a practical decision. Real-world problem-solving context.
SEP Justification: Students analyze quantitative data from a topographic map to make a decision. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data and Using Mathematics and Computational Thinking to compare relative steepness.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that wider contour spacing indicates gentler slopes. Applied understanding of topographic map interpretation with quantitative comparison.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — students identify the pattern that wider spacing = gentler slope. Also engages Cause and Effect (spacing determines steepness experienced).
Key Recommendation: Excellent applied topographic reasoning question. One of the strongest items. Could elevate further by asking students to calculate approximate slope angles or explain why wider spacing means a gentler slope.

Stem: A hiker has a topographic map showing a river running north-south. On the east side of the river contour lines are 2 cm apart. On the west side contour lines are 0.5 cm apart. Which statement correctly describes the terrain?
Image/Diagram Description: Topographic map showing river with different contour spacings on each side
Choices: A) East side is steep and west side is gradual, B) West side is steep and east side is gradual making it easier to climb, C) Both sides have the same steepness, D) The river flows uphill on the west side
Scenario Justification: Strong applied scenario requiring students to interpret contour line spacing on both sides of a river and correctly translate spacing to terrain description. Builds on topographic reasoning from Q10.
SEP Justification: Students analyze and interpret topographic map data to describe terrain features. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data from a scientific representation.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the inverse relationship between contour line spacing and slope steepness. Applied interpretation of topographic representations.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — recognizing that spacing patterns indicate different terrain characteristics on each side of the river.
Key Recommendation: Good companion to Q10. Could elevate by asking students to explain WHY wider contour spacing indicates gentler slopes or to predict what the hiker would experience crossing from one side to the other.

Stem: A family lives in a hurricane-prone area and must protect 10 windows. Plywood costs $50 per window and takes 45 minutes per window to install with a 3-5 year lifespan. Roll-down shutters cost $300 per window and deploy in seconds with a 10-15 year lifespan. Budget is $3500, minimal storage space, and family is often away during hurricanes. Which solution is best?
Choices: A) Plywood because it is the cheapest option, B) Plywood because it provides better protection, C) Roll-down shutters because they last longer, D) Roll-down shutters because they can be deployed remotely while the family is traveling
Scenario Justification: Excellent engineering design problem with multiple explicit constraints: budget ($3500), number of windows (10), storage limitations, time constraints, and the critical factor that the family is often away. Students must weigh multiple trade-offs simultaneously.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate competing solutions against multiple criteria and constraints. Engages Designing Solutions and Engaging in Argument from Evidence by selecting and justifying the best solution based on constraint analysis.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding engineering design trade-offs including cost, durability, ease of use, and practical constraints. Applied ETS reasoning with real-world complexity.
CCC Justification: Strongly engages Systems and System Models — students must consider how multiple constraints interact as a system to determine the optimal solution. Also engages Cause and Effect (being away causes inability to install plywood).
Key Recommendation: One of the strongest items on this test. Excellent multi-constraint engineering problem. Could add a Part B asking what the family should choose if they were always home during hurricane season.

Stem: A library needs flood protection meeting these requirements: at least 25 inches of protection, installation in less than 5 hours, lasting at least 5 seasons, budget of $5500. Which option is MOST appropriate? Option details provided for multiple solutions.
Choices: A) Sandbag wall — 20 inches protection, B) Aluminum flood gates — 30 inches protection and 4.5 hours installation and $5400 cost and 12-year lifespan, C) Inflatable barrier — 28 inches protection and 6 hours installation, D) Concrete barrier — 36 inches protection and $7000 cost
Scenario Justification: Excellent engineering design problem requiring systematic evaluation of four solutions against four specific constraints. Students must check each option against all criteria and identify the only one that meets every requirement. Strong constraint-based reasoning.
SEP Justification: Students systematically evaluate multiple solutions against quantitative criteria. Engages Designing Solutions and Analyzing and Interpreting Data by comparing specifications to requirements.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding how to systematically evaluate engineering solutions against defined criteria. Applied ETS reasoning with quantitative comparison.
CCC Justification: Strongly engages Systems and System Models — each constraint functions as part of a system of requirements. Students must consider all constraints together. Also engages Patterns in systematic comparison.
Key Recommendation: Excellent constraint-evaluation question. Each distractor fails on exactly one criterion (A: height; C: time; D: budget), making the reasoning clear and systematic. Could add a Part B about trade-offs if the budget increased.

Stem: Three balls are tested: Ball P travels 18 meters in 6 seconds (3 m/s). Ball Q travels 12 meters in 3 seconds (4 m/s). Ball R travels 15 meters in 5 seconds (3 m/s). Which statement correctly explains the relationship between speed and energy?
Choices: A) Ball P has the most energy because it traveled the farthest, B) Ball Q has the most energy because it has the highest speed at 4 m/s, C) Ball R has the most energy because it traveled a moderate distance, D) All three balls have the same energy because they all moved
Scenario Justification: Data-based scenario requiring students to calculate or compare speeds from distance and time data and then link speed to kinetic energy. Quantitative reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students analyze quantitative data to determine speed and rank energy. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data with mathematical reasoning required to calculate speeds.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that speed determines kinetic energy (for same-mass objects) and that speed must be derived from distance/time data. Applied understanding of energy and motion.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — students calculate speeds and identify the pattern that greater speed corresponds to greater energy. Also engages Energy and Matter.
Key Recommendation: Good quantitative reasoning question. Strengthen by including balls of different masses and asking how both mass and speed affect kinetic energy to deepen the analysis.

Stem: Object X is at 35 degrees C and Object Y is at 15 degrees C. They are placed in contact. Later Object X is at 30 degrees C and Object Y is at 20 degrees C. Which statement explains the heat transfer?
Choices: A) Heat transferred from X to Y because heat flows from higher to lower temperature, B) Heat transferred from Y to X because Y needed more energy, C) Both objects lost heat to the surroundings, D) No heat transfer occurred because the objects are different materials
Scenario Justification: Real scenario with specific temperature data showing changes after contact. Students must interpret the data and apply the principle that heat flows from warmer to cooler objects.
SEP Justification: Students analyze temperature data and construct an explanation for the observed changes. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data and Constructing Explanations from quantitative evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that thermal energy transfers from higher-temperature objects to lower-temperature objects. Applied understanding with specific temperature values as evidence.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — temperature difference (cause) drives heat transfer (effect). Also engages Energy and Matter — energy flows from hot to cold.
Key Recommendation: Good data-driven heat transfer question. Elevate by asking students to predict the final equilibrium temperature or explain why the objects did not reach the same temperature yet.

Stem: A student builds a circuit with a switch, battery, wires, and bulb. When the switch is closed the bulb does not light. The battery and bulb both work when tested separately. What is the most likely cause?
Choices: A) There is a break in the conducting path, B) The switch is too far from the battery, C) The bulb needs two batteries, D) The wires are too long
Scenario Justification: Troubleshooting scenario where students must diagnose why a circuit is not working despite functional components. Students must reason about what could prevent current flow when all individual parts work.
SEP Justification: Students engage in diagnostic reasoning similar to Planning and Carrying Out Investigations and Constructing Explanations. Must reason from evidence (components work individually) to identify the cause of failure.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that a complete conducting path is necessary for current flow. Applied understanding of circuit principles in a troubleshooting context.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — the break in the path (cause) prevents current flow and the bulb from lighting (effect). Students reason diagnostically about causation.
Key Recommendation: Good diagnostic reasoning question. Strengthen by asking students to describe what steps they would take to find and fix the break, engaging Planning and Carrying Out Investigations.

Stem: A circuit has two switches connected in series with a battery and a bulb. Only the first switch is closed. Why doesn't the bulb light?
Choices: A) The first switch is blocking the current, B) The battery is not strong enough for two switches, C) The conducting path is incomplete because the second switch is open preventing current flow, D) The bulb only works when one switch is present
Scenario Justification: Builds on circuit concepts from Q16 by introducing series switches. Students must understand that all switches in a series circuit must be closed for current to flow. Applied reasoning about circuit completeness.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation for why the circuit fails. Engages Constructing Explanations about circuit behavior based on understanding of series connections.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that a series circuit needs a complete path through all components. Applied understanding of circuit principles with added complexity of multiple switches.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — the open second switch (cause) breaks the conducting path preventing current flow (effect). Also engages Systems and System Models at a basic level.
Key Recommendation: Good companion to Q16 adding complexity with series switches. Could elevate by asking students to compare series vs. parallel switch arrangements and predict outcomes.

Stem: Which appliance demonstrates the conversion of electrical energy to mechanical energy to sound energy?
Choices: A) A ceiling fan that creates noise while its blades rotate, B) A lamp that produces light, C) A radio that plays music, D) A heater that warms a room
Scenario Justification: Asks students to identify a specific three-step energy conversion chain. Some reasoning required to trace electrical to mechanical to sound but limited authentic scenario.
SEP Justification: Students identify a device matching a specific energy conversion sequence. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a basic matching level — tracing energy transformations through a device.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the full chain of energy conversions in a ceiling fan: electrical energy powers motor (mechanical) which creates vibrations/noise (sound). Applied understanding of energy transformations.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Energy and Matter (energy transformation chain) but the reasoning demand is modest.
Key Recommendation: The energy chain concept is good but presented as simple matching. Redesign to give students data about energy inputs and outputs of several devices and ask them to construct and explain the conversion chains.

Stem: Which device converts electrical energy to heat energy as its main function?
Choices: A) A flashlight, B) A radio, C) A fan, D) An electric toaster
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Direct recall of which device primarily converts electrical to heat energy. No reasoning required.
SEP Justification: No science practice engaged. Pure recall and classification of a device by its primary energy conversion.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge that a toaster converts electrical energy primarily to heat. Recall-level understanding.
CCC Justification: No CCC engaged.
Key Recommendation: Pure recall. Redesign by providing energy input/output data for multiple devices and asking students to identify patterns in energy conversions and explain why some devices produce heat as a byproduct vs. primary function.

Stem: Students are presenting science fair projects. Which project contributes LEAST to air pollution?
Choices: A) A model car powered by a small gasoline engine, B) A miniature windmill that converts air energy into motion and light, C) A small coal-burning steam engine, D) A wood-burning camp stove
Scenario Justification: Scenario with multiple energy projects. Students must compare pollution impacts across four options. Some analysis required but the answer is straightforward — renewable vs. combustion sources.
SEP Justification: Students compare and evaluate energy sources based on environmental impact. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data at a basic comparison level.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that wind energy does not produce air pollutants while combustion does. Basic recall of renewable vs. nonrenewable energy impacts.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (combustion causes pollution; wind does not) but the reasoning is minimal.
Key Recommendation: The science fair framing is good but the question is simple categorization. Strengthen by providing air quality data from each project and asking students to analyze patterns and make recommendations.

Stem: A sound wave completes 3 cycles per second. A water wave takes 2 seconds to complete 1 cycle. Both have the same amplitude. Which statement correctly describes these waves?
Choices: A) The sound wave has a lower frequency than the water wave, B) Both waves have the same frequency and wavelength, C) The water wave has a lower frequency and a longer wavelength, D) The sound wave has a longer wavelength than the water wave
Scenario Justification: Quantitative wave comparison requiring students to determine frequency from given data and then relate frequency to wavelength. Multi-step reasoning with specific numerical data.
SEP Justification: Students analyze quantitative data about two waves to compare frequency and wavelength. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data and Using Mathematics and Computational Thinking.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the relationship between frequency and wavelength (inverse relationship) and the ability to determine frequency from cycles-per-time data. Applied understanding of wave properties.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — students identify the pattern that lower frequency corresponds to longer wavelength. Also engages Cause and Effect in the inverse relationship between frequency and wavelength.
Key Recommendation: Good quantitative wave comparison. Strengthen by providing wave diagrams and asking students to draw and label the amplitude, wavelength, and frequency for each wave.

Stem: Rain washes soil from a construction site into a nearby stream. Which action would BEST prevent this from happening?
Choices: A) Install a silt fence along the edge of the construction site, B) Build a dam across the stream, C) Plant flowers in the stream, D) Cover the stream with a tarp
Scenario Justification: Real-world erosion and runoff problem at a construction site. Students must evaluate solutions and select the most practical and effective one for preventing sediment from entering the stream.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate competing solutions to an erosion and runoff problem. Engages Designing Solutions and Constructing Explanations about why a silt fence prevents sediment transport.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding erosion, sediment transport by water, and how physical barriers can intercept sediment before it enters waterways. Applied understanding of Earth surface processes.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect — rain causes erosion and the silt fence blocks sediment transport (cause of solution). Also engages Systems and System Models at a basic level (construction site, runoff, stream as interconnected).
Key Recommendation: Good applied question connecting erosion to real-world solutions. Strengthen by providing data on sediment levels with and without silt fences and asking students to analyze the effectiveness.
